title: Flexible Demand Manipulation

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We develop a simple framework to analyze how targeted advertising interacts with market power. A designer chooses an advertising plan which allows it to flexibly manipulate the demand curve at some cost. A monopolist prices against this manipulated demand curve. We fully characterize the form and value of producer-optimal and consumer-optimal advertising plans under both ex-ante and ex-post measures of welfare. Flexibility is double-edged: producer-optimal plans substantially reduce consumer surplus vis-a-vis uniform advertising, but consumer-optimal plans can substantially improve consumer surplus. We discuss implications for the regulation of targeted advertising.


[^0]
[^0]:    *MIT Department of Economics; email: yfdai@mit.edu
    ${ }^{\dagger}$ MIT Department of Economics; email: ajkoh@mit.edu
    First posted version: February 2024
    We are particularly grateful to Drew Fudenberg and Stephen Morris for guidance, support, and many insightful suggestions. We also thank Alessandro Bonatti, Ian Ball, Roberto Corrao, Andrea Galeotti, Matt Elliott, Nima Haghpanah, Ellen Muir, Yucheng Shang, Teck Yong Tan, and Alex Wolitzky for helpful discussions. We benefitted from collaboration with Shijian Yang in the preliminary stages of this project. We also thank participants at the MIT Summer 2023 Theory Lab and MIT Behavioral, Theory and IO lunches for comments.

# 1 Introduction Targeted advertising is a central feature of modern markets. ${ }^{1}$ Because of their ubiquity and implications for welfare, it has accordingly received considerable attention from policymakers. ${ }^{2}$ Indeed many legislators have called for, or implemented bans on targeted advertising: European regulators recently banned Meta, a large social media company, from using personal data to target ads. Similarly, in the US the proposed American Privacy Rights Act-intended to "establish national consumer data privacy rights and set standards for data security"-proposes to prohibit allow targeted ads based on protected class and personal data purchased from data brokers. These policies have been largely driven by privacy concerns-that is, concerns over how firms acquire data to personalize their advertisements, and the attendant implications for data protection. However, the impact of targeted advertising qua targeted advertising on prices and welfare remains unclear: how does the ability to precisely advertise at precise segments of the population influence a monopolist's pricing decisions? What are the implications for regulation and welfare? Motivated by these questions, we develop a simple but novel framework for studying the interplay between targeted advertising and market power. Advertising in our environment is entirely persuasive in the sense that it increases willingness to pay directly. ${ }^{3}$ In our model, a designer chooses an optimal advertising plan where the cost of transporting type $x$ to the higher valuation $y$ is $c(x, y) .{ }^{4}$ Implicit in this formulation are two kinds of precision: the designer's ability to - Target precisely is reflected by its ability to increase the valuations of types $x$ and $x^{\prime}$ by different amounts. This reflects a distinct feature of online advertising where the costs of targeting different kinds and quantities of ads at different consumers are dramatically reduced (Goldfarb, 2014). - Persuade precisely is reflected by its ability to transport the valuation of type $x$ to exactly $y$. This reflects the increasing persuasiveness of new technologies such as artificial intelligence, especially for marketing consumer products (Matz et al., 2024). ${ }^{5}$ [^0] [^0]: ${ }^{1}$ Expenditure in the US on targeted advertising has tripled between 2017 and 2022. ${ }^{2}$ For instance, in 2018 the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) went into effect; in the US, California has implemented a GDPR-like law with several more states to follow suit in 2023. ${ }^{3}$ This stands in contrast to "informative" advertising in which consumers learn about the existence or quality of a product. See, e.g., Kaldor (1950) for an early discussion of this distinction. ${ }^{4}$ This is a directional optimal transportation problem studied recently by Nutz and Wang (2022) from which we have found helpful to borrow language and basic results. ${ }^{5}$ Matz et al. (2024) find experimentally that personalized messages by language models "exhibit significantly more influence than non-personalized messages... across different domains of Together, precision in targeting and persuasion allow the designer to flexibly manipulate demand: any demand curve which first-order stochastically dominates the original one is feasible (at some cost). Facing this transformed distribution, a monopolist optimally sets a posted price. We are interested in what combinations of producer and consumer surplus are implementable, and the forms of advertising plans which implement them. We use this to develop sharp implications for the regulation of targeted advertising. Example 1. We begin with a simple parametric example which illustrates the power of flexible demand manipulation. Consider a canonical monopoly pricing environment where the initial valuation of consumers is uniform over the $[0,1]$ interval. A designer can, by targeting different kinds and quantities of persuasive ads at different consumers, precisely manipulate willingness to pay. The cost of increasing the willingness to pay of type $x$ to $y>x$ is proportional to the quadratic distance. Figure 1 illustrates the welfare possibilities from flexibly manipulating the demand curve. For this example we focus on ex-ante consumer surplus i.e., welfare with respect to initial rather than final valuations-surplus for certain consumers can thus be negative; in the main text we also analyze the ex-post case. Figure 1: The power of flexible demand manipulation ![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg) Consumer Surplus (ex-ante) No advertisements. First observe that sans advertisements, the monopolist charges an optimal price of $1 / 2$ and consumer surplus is $1 / 8$. The corresponding welfare outcome is illustrated by the black dot in Figure 1. This is the familiar monopoly pricing problem which trades-off the intensive margin against the extensive margin and is illustrated in the first panel of Figure 2. Uniform advertising. Next consider the case of uniform advertising in which all consumers must be shifted by the same amount. This improves producer surplus and decreases ex-ante consumer surplus by pushing up the monopolist's price to [^0] [^0]: persuasion (e.g., marketing of consumer products)". 4/7; this is illustrated by the pink dot in Figure 1. ${ }^{6}$ This uniform shift to the demand curve is illustrated in the second panel of Figure 2. Producer-optimal flexible advertising. Now consider the producer-optimal advertising plan under full flexibility. The corresponding welfare outcome is illustrated by the red dot in Figure 1. This exacerbates the impact on consumer welfare: with finer control, the monopolist chooses a substantially higher price of $\approx 0.82$ and shores up demand via flexibly targeted advertisements as illustrated by the third panel of Figure 2. Figure 2: The workings of flexible demand manipulation ![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg) Consumer-optimal flexible advertising. Finally, consider the consumer-optimal advertising plan under full flexibility. The corresponding welfare outcome is illustrated by the blue dot in Figure 1. By carefully choosing the advertising plan, the designer is able to induce the monopolist to set a low price of $\approx 0.26$ and deliver substantially (i) more consumer surplus; and (ii) more gains from trade. How the demand curve is optimally manipulated to induce this outcome is illustrated by the last panel of Figure 2. Example 1 fully characterizes the form and value of flexible demand manipulation in a simple environment with uniform demand and quadratic transportation costs. We will generalize and extend these insights; doing so will unveil a richer picture of optimal advertising plans-and how they should be regulated. Outline of contribution. We first characterize the form of advertising maps which maximize any combination of producer and consumer surplus. Some care is required in how we measure consumer welfare: ${ }^{7}$ - Ex-ante welfare: a consumer transported from $x$ to $y$ and buys the product at price $p$ and enjoys a surplus with respect to her previous valuation $x-p$ which can be negative if $x

# 2 Model 

Initial valuations. There is a unit measure of consumers with values $v$ supported on an interval $X \subseteq \mathbb{R}_{+}$according to the atomless distribution $\mu \in \Delta\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)$with $\operatorname{CDF} F$ and density $f>0$ (except perhaps on the boundary of $X$ ). We assume that $\min X=$ 0 so valuations start from 0 , but can be either bounded or unbounded. When $X$ is bounded, we denote the highest valuation as $\tilde{v}:=\max X$. Assume that $F$ admits an increasing hazard rate (IHR) such that $f /(1-F)$ is nondecreasing. ${ }^{16}$
Notation. Define the pushforward measure $(T)_{\#} \mu(A):=\mu\left(T^{-1}(A)\right)$ whenever $A$ is measurable. Given the probability measure $v$ denote the CDF with $F_{v}$, the "survival function" with $\bar{F}_{v}(x):=v([x, \infty))$, and Pseudo-inverse with $F_{v}^{-1} .{ }^{17}$ For a function $T$ on $\mathbb{R}_{+}$, (id, $T$ ) is the map that maps $x \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$to $(x, T(x))$. Given a measure $\pi \in \Delta\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{2}\right)$, we denote the marginal over the first coordinate by $\operatorname{marg}_{x} \pi$ and the other marginal by $\operatorname{marg}_{y} \pi$. We say $\pi$ is induced by a map $T$ on $\mathbb{R}_{+}$if $\pi=(\mathrm{id}, T)_{\#} \mu$. Finally, let $\leq_{s t}$ denote the FOSD order.

Advertising as transportation. We consider the setting where a designer can perfectly target consumers with different initial valuations, increasing their valuations through ads at a cost. That is, the designer chooses an advertising plan, which is a joint distribution $\pi \in \Delta\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{2}\right)$ : the first marginal is the original distribution (i.e., $\left.\operatorname{marg}_{x} \pi=\mu\right)$, the second marginal is the target distribution. Consumers make decisions independently, so the cost of persuading a consumer only depends on their initial and final valuation. We also assume that there are no economies of scale in advertising-that is, the total cost is simply the sum of individual costs. ${ }^{18}$

This (individual) cost is denoted by a function $c: \mathbb{R}_{+}^{2} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$, and the cost of an advertising plan $\pi$ is the aggregate of individual costs $\int c(x, y) d \pi$. We maintain throughout the following assumptions on $c$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{15}$ The problem of choosing a target distribution over final valuations is related to recent work characterizing extreme points of bounded FOSD distributions (Yang and Zentefis, 2023). Our problem is neither bounded nor is the objective function convex so the optimal target distribution need not be (and typically is not) an extreme point.
    ${ }^{16}$ We further note that for our main results characterizing the form of optimal advertising plans, we will require only that the distribution's tail grows strictly slower than $1 / x$ to guarantee the existence of an optimal price.
    ${ }^{17}$ The definition of $\bar{F}_{v}$ reflects our assumption that the consumers break ties in favor of the monopolist. $F_{v}^{-1}(x)=\inf \left\{t \in \mathbb{R}: F_{v}(t) \geq x\right\}$
    ${ }^{18}$ This corresponds to a world in which the marginal cost of personalizing advertisements based on user data is near-zero (see, for instance, the rise of AI copywriting tools), and the bulk of the cost of advertising is from reaching consumers.

Assumption 1. The cost function $c$ is
(i) twice continuously differentiable;
(ii) $c(x, x)=c_{y}(x, x)=0$ for every $x \geq 0$ and $c_{y y}>0$ on $\mathbb{R}_{+}^{2}$;
(iii) strictly submodular; and
(iv) there exists some constants $K>0, k>1$ such that for all $x \in X$,

$$
y-x \geq K \Longrightarrow c(x, y)>k(y-x)
$$

Assumptions (i) and (ii) are regularity conditions; Assumption (iii) states that the marginal cost of increasing the final valuation is decreasing in the initial valuation. For instance, (a) the cost of scaling up a consumer's initial valuation by some fixed proportion is the same across consumer types; or (b) consumers are equally susceptible to advertisements and the cost of moving type $x$ to $y>x$ is a convex function of $|y-x|$ (i.e., only dependent on the distance moved). Assumption (iv) states that the cost increasing valuations must eventually increase quicker than one-for-one which guarantees existence. ${ }^{19}$

We will focus our attention to advertising plans which weakly increase valuations. ${ }^{20}$ This implies that for a given distribution over initial valuations $\mu \in \Delta(X)$ and a choice of final valuations $v \in \Delta\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)$, the choice or advertising plan is a directional optimal transportation problem (Nutz and Wang, 2022). Writing $\mathbb{H}:=$ $\left\{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{2}: y \geq x\right\}$, we will have the additional directional constraint that $\pi(\mathbb{H})=1$. Thus, the set of feasible advertising plans is

$$
\Pi:=\left\{\pi \in \Delta\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{2}\right): \operatorname{marg}_{x} \pi=\mu, \pi(\mathbb{H})=1\right\}
$$

Welfare metric. As usual, we associate producer surplus with profits. However, there is some subtlety in how we define consumer welfare in our environment. We offer two welfare measures:
(i) Ex-ante consumer surplus (denoted $C S^{A}$ ) is CS measured relative to valuations under the initial distribution. That is, if the price is $p$ and the transport map is $\pi$,

$$
C S^{A}(p, \pi)=\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{2}} \mathbb{I}(y \geq p)(x-p) d \pi(x, y)
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{19}$ This is weaker than an "Inada-type" condition which would require that the marginal cost of increasing valuations goes to infinity.
    ${ }^{20}$ Clearly, relaxing the directional constraint cannot improve producer surplus; more subtly, it can sometimes improve consumer surplus by relaxing the monopolist's upward deviation constraints. See also $\mathrm{Li}(2023)$ who studies a model where consumers are 'mismatched' to firms which can induce lower prices.

noting that this depends on the joint map $\pi$ since welfare depends on both buying decisions (final valuations) and surplus (price less initial valuations).
(ii) Ex-post consumer surplus (denoted $C S^{p}$ ) is CS measured relative to valuations under the final distribution. That is, if the price is $p$ and the transport map is $\pi$,

$$
C S^{p}(p, \pi):=\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{p}} \mathbb{I}(y \geq p)(y-p) d \pi(x, y)=\int_{p}^{+\infty}(y-p) \mathrm{d} F_{v}(y)
$$

noting that this depends only on the target distribution $v$.
The appropriate welfare measure will depend on how advertising is interpreted. Ex-ante consumer surplus reflects advertising as manipulation: it does not change "true" valuations so consumers transported from $x$ to $y$ and who purchase at a price $p$ with $x<p<y$ can receive negative surplus (of $x-p<0$ ). Under this view, advertising creates a wedge between choice and preferences: consumers choose to purchase although they might be better off not doing so. There are many behavioral mechanisms underlying this phenomena (Armstrong, 2010); we are agnostic about the exact mechanism. On the other hand, the formulation of ex-post consumer surplus is consistent with the view of advertising as a complementary good (Stigler and Becker, 1977) since advertising increases consumers' "true" valuations. This is also in line with the revealed preference approach to measuring consumer welfare.

Timing. We will suppose throughout that consumers break ties in favor of buying and the monopolist breaks ties in favor of the lowest price. The timing of the game is as follows:

1. Designer chooses the joint distribution $\pi \in \Pi$ from the set of feasible advertising plans which maps initial valuations $(x)$ to the target valuation $(y)$ such that the target distribution of valuations is $\operatorname{mar}_{p} \pi$
2. Monopolist faces the target distribution $\operatorname{mar}_{p} \pi$ and chooses the lowest price $p_{\operatorname{mar}_{\mathrm{p}} \pi}^{*}$ which solves the monopoly pricing problem $\sup _{p} p \bar{F}_{\operatorname{mar}_{\mathrm{p}} \pi}(p)$.
3. Consumers face price $p_{\operatorname{mar}_{\mathrm{p}} \pi}^{*}$ and choose whether or not to purchase based on their final valuations.
4. Payoffs $P S(\pi), C S^{A}(\pi)$, and $C S^{P}(\pi)$ are realized, noting that we write welfare as a function only of $\pi$ since dependence on prices comes through $\pi$ via monopoly pricing.

Designer's problem. The designer's objective is to maximize some convex combination of consumer surplus (ex-post or ex-ante) less advertising costs. Her prob-

lems under the ex-ante consumer and ex-post consumer welfare measures are

$$
\sup _{\pi \in \Pi}\left[\underbrace{\alpha \cdot C S^{A}(\pi)+(1-\alpha) \cdot P S(\pi)}_{\text {Weighted combination of } C S^{A} \text { and } P S}-\int_{\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}} c(x, y) \mathrm{d} \pi(x, y)\right]
$$

(D: ex-ante)
and

$$
\sup _{\pi \in \Pi}\left[\underbrace{\alpha \cdot C S^{P}(\pi)+(1-\alpha) \cdot P S(\pi)}_{\text {Weighted combination of } C S^{P} \text { and } P S}-\int_{\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}} c(x, y) \mathrm{d} \pi(x, y)\right]
$$

where $\alpha \in[0,1]$ is the weight the designer places on consumer welfare.
Discussion. It will be helpful to interpret our model.

- Advertising as manipulation vs complements. One interpretation of advertising is that it is purely persuasive-that is, it is able to increase valuations by altering preferences directly, or by exploiting behavioral biases. Different views have different implications for how we should model consumer welfare (Bernheim, 2009, 2016); we will analyze optimal advertising plans for each of these welfare metrics.
- Interpreting the cost function. Our view of advertising is persuasive so that advertisements directly improve willingness-to-pay. We model such changes via a cost function which is continuously increasing in the final valuation. This might comprise of the cost-per-unit-time of accessing a consumer scaled by the responsiveness of valuations to ads. Importantly, we are agnostic about the exact mechanism through which valuations change (see Armstrong (2010) and references therein for different possible behavioral mechanisms). Furthermore, we have implicitly assumed that consumers with the same valuations are equally costly to manipulate. In practice, consumers might differ both along valuations and along susceptibility to manipulation. Our analysis extends readily to richer environments with multidimensional heterogeneity along both valuations and susceptibility to manipulation, albeit at the cost of additional notation. We detail this in Appendix E.
- Uniform pricing. In our model, the designer is perfectly informed about consumer types. This raises the question of whether the monopolist is similarly informed and, if so, why has it not engaged in price discrimination? One possibility is that the monopolist is simply uninformed, as in the case where the designer is a large platform with detailed information about consumers' preferences while the monopolist is simply a seller. A second possibility is

that the monopolist is unable to price discriminate because of reputational or other concerns. ${ }^{21}$ Whatever the reason, personalized advertisements with uniform pricing remain the prevailing state of affairs in both on- and offline marketplaces. ${ }^{22}$

- Interpreting the designer. Our designer can be interpreted as an intermediary e.g., platform facilitating trade between sellers on one side, and consumers on the other. Platforms have incentive to balance the surplus on both sides of the market: on the one hand, they typically charge a commission on sales; ${ }^{23}$ on the other, they have incentive to deliver consumer surplus since consumers might have the option to buy off-platform; Appendix D develops a simple model of intermediated targeted advertising and shows that our results apply there. ${ }^{24}$ An alternative interpretation is that our designer serves as an analytical tool to understand the limits of how flexible demand manipulation can shape both total welfare as well the surplus split. ${ }^{25}$

# 3 Advertising as manipulation 

We start by considering the view of advertising as manipulation. This reflects an old disquiet about advertising: "If the individual's wants are to be urgent. ... they must be original with himself. They cannot be urgent if they must be contrived for him. ... One cannot defend production as satisfying wants if that production creates the wants" (Galbraith, 1958). Under this view, advertising leads to a wedge between preferences and choices; ${ }^{26}$ see, e.g. Bernheim $(2009,2016)$ : the choice to purchase is driven by transported valuations although preferences are driven by initial valuations. ${ }^{27}$ This, our notion of consumer welfare is ex-ante. Our first result pins

    ${ }^{22}$ In offline marketplaces, uniform pricing remains the norm. In online marketplaces, personalized pricing seems-at least for now-relatively scarce. Cavallo and Rigobon (2016) show a remarkable degree of similarity between online and offline prices. On the other hand, targeted online advertising is ubiquitous: US spending on online advertising reached $\$ 271$ Billion USD in 2022, roughly triple from 91 Billion USD in 2017. See also Goldfarb (2014) for a discussion of how online advertising substantially reduces the cost of targeting ads.
    ${ }^{23}$ For instance, Amazon typically charges a differential commission based on product category, ranging from $1 \%$ for grocery to up to $20 \%$ for Amazon games.
    ${ }^{24}$ See also Bergemann and Bonatti (2024) for a model of on-vs-off platform interaction. Elliott, Galeotti, Koh, and Li (2022) characterizes all welfare outcomes a platform can implement via controlling access and information. Persuasive advertising is absent in both papers.

    ${ }^{26}$ This is consistent with—but not reliant on-the view of welfare as preference satisfaction.
    ${ }^{27}$ This is similar to the notion of "glossiness" of products recently suggested by Acemoglu, Makhdoumi, Malekian, and Ozdaglar (2023) in which a seller can lead consumers to misperceive

down the general form of optimal advertising plans.
Theorem 1. For any weight on ex-ante consumer surplus $\alpha \in[0,1]$, the designer's problem under ex-ante welfare measure (D: ex-ante) is uniquely solved by a deterministic advertising plan $\pi^{*} \in \Pi$ which takes the following intermediate interval structure:

$$
T(x)= \begin{cases}x & \text { if } x \geq p^{*} \\ p^{*} & \text { if } x \in\left[\underline{p}, p^{*}\right) \\ x & \text { if } x<\underline{p}\end{cases}
$$

for some $p^{*} \geq \underline{p}$, where $T(x)$ is the valuation type $x$ is transported to.

Figure 3: Form of optimal advertising plans (ex-ante)
![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)

Theorem 1 is illustrated in Figure 3 which depicts the inverse demand function (panel (a)) and advertising map (panel (b)). Such plans consist of a target price $p^{*}$ which the designer aims to implement, and a target quantity $\bar{F}(\underline{p})$. The designer then (deterministically) transports all types between $\underline{p}$ to $p^{*}$ such as to shore up demand. ${ }^{28}$

Figure 4 illustrates the simple reason why optimal maps must take this form. Panel (a) depicts maps from $x$ to $y$ which must be suboptimal i.e., if an advertising plan assigns positive probability to such maps, it can be strictly improved. Start by considering the arrow on the left which maps valuation $x<p^{*}$ to $y<p^{*}$. Since the consumer does not purchase, advertising is entirely wasteful and the designer is better off not advertising to those consumers. Next, consider the arrow in the middle which maps valuations $x<p^{*}$ to $y>p^{*}$, and the arrow on the right which

[^0]
[^0]:    the true quality of the product. In the language of our paper, this transports consumers' willingness to pay.
    ${ }^{28}$ That is, the solution is given by a "Monge map" without splitting mass.

Figure 4: Intuition for intermediate interval maps
![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)
maps valuations $p^{*}<x$ to $y>x>p^{*}$. In both cases, advertising is excessive for two distinct reasons: such maps are

1. wasteful because transporting valuations from $x$ to $p^{*}$ if $x<p^{*}$ and not advertising otherwise would (i) save on advertising costs; (ii) still suffice to induce purchase at price $p^{*}$ (PS does not decrease); and (iii) under ex-ante consumer surplus, excess willingness-to-pay does not translate to excess welfare; and
2. tempting because the consumers transported to $y>p^{*}$ would continue to purchase the product if the monopolist deviates upward to price $p^{*}<p^{*} \leq y$. This tightens the monopolist's upward deviation constraints and makes the target price $p^{*}$ more challenging to implement.

Both of these forces act in the same direction and imply that only consumers with initial valuations $x<p^{*}$ can be targeted and, if they are, must be transported to exactly $p^{*}$; inframarginal consumers are never shown advertisements. Which among consumers with valuations $x<p^{*}$ should be targeted? Panel (b) illustrates why the "greedy choice" which starts with marginal consumers with valuations just shy of the price $p^{*}$ and working backwards is optimal.

Indeed, the above argument applies quite generally, and this intermediate interval form remains optimal beyond the class of additive objective functions considered by the problem (D: ex-ante). Appendix A develops a suitable generalization to objective functions which are weakly increasing in producer and consumer surplus, and decreasing in advertising expenditure (Theorem 1B). We apply this in Appendix D to analyze an intermediary's optimal advertising plan when the size of the market (measure of consumers) is endogeneous-so the objective function is multiplicative in consumer and producer surplus.

Theorem 1 establishes the form of optimal advertising plans is qualitatively similar across consumer-optimal and producer-optimal plans. Nonetheless, the economic intuition underlying these plans differ, and these are reflected in different target prices and target quantities.

Producer-optimal plans. Maximizing producer surplus is equivalent to the monopolist choosing both $p^{*}$ and the advertising plan $\pi$ directly. Holding fixed the target distribution, the monopolist faces the standard tradeoff between her extensive margin (selling to fewer customers) with her intensive margin (selling to existing consumers at higher prices). However, by varying the advertising plan $\pi$, the monopolist is also able to artificially shore up demand. Thus, the ability to flexibly target advertising means that the monopolist's intensive-extensive tradeoff is no longer local.

This suggests a simple one-dimensional characterization of the producer-optimal plan: for a given target price $p^{*}, \underline{p}$ is pinned down as the highest quantity so that the contribution to producer surplus from transporting $\underline{p}$ to $p^{*}$ is exactly offset by the cost of doing so. Hence, the additional extensive margin is determined by the marginal cost of advertising. This is depicted by Figure 5 (a) and formalized by the following proposition.

Proposition 1 (Producer-optimal). The producer-optimal plan is solved by the intermediate interval transport map of Theorem 1 where $\left(\underline{p}, p^{*}\right)$ solves

$$
\begin{aligned}
\max _{p \geq 0} & {\left[p \bar{F}(\underline{p}(p))-\int_{\underline{p}(p)}^{p} c(x, p) d \pi\right] } \\
& \text { with } \underline{p}(p):=\inf \{x \in \mathbb{R}: c(x, p)=p\}
\end{aligned}
$$

We will subsequently use Proposition 1 to show that a monopolist equipped with the ability to flexibly manipulate the demand curve typically drives prices up relative to uniform advertising.

Figure 5: Producer and consumer-optimal plans
![img-4.jpeg](img-4.jpeg)

Consumer-optimal plans. Maximizing ex-ante consumer surplus is more subtle

because for $p^{*}$ to be implementable, the target demand curve must be such that the monopolist does not find it profitable to deviate to any higher price $p^{\prime}>p^{*}$. The designer's instrument to implement a low target price $p^{*}$ is to shore up demand by transporting types $x \in\left[p, p^{*}\right]$ to $p^{*}$. The core tradeoff here is that to implement the lower target price $p^{*}$, the monopolist shores up demand which is associated with (i) the costs of advertising; and (ii) welfare losses from transported consumers $x \in\left[p, p^{*}\right]$ who are manipulated into buying the product and receive an individual surplus of $x-p^{*}<0$.

This suggests a one-dimensional characterization of the consumer-optimal plan: for a given target price $p^{*}, p$ is pinned down as the highest threshold which can implement $p^{*}$. Hence, the additional extensive margin is determined by the monopolist's upward deviation constraints. This is depicted in Figure 5 (b) and is formalized by the following proposition.

Proposition 2 (Ex-ante consumer-optimal). The ex-ante consumer-optimal plan is solved by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \max _{p \geq 0}[\underbrace{\int_{p}^{+\infty}(x-p) d F(x)}_{\text {Ex-ante CS }}-\underbrace{\int_{p}^{p}(c(x, p)+(p-x)) d F(x)}_{\text {Transportation and manipulation cost }}] \\
& \text { where } \underline{p}(p):=\sup \left\{\hat{p} \in[0, p]: \underbrace{p \bar{F}(\hat{p}) \geq p^{\prime} \bar{F}\left(p^{\prime}\right)}_{\text {upward deviations }} \quad \forall p^{\prime} \geq p\right\} \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

Furthermore, $p^{*}<p^{M}$ i.e., the monopolist's price strictly decreases, and the upward deviation to $p^{M}$ binds: $p^{*} \bar{F}\left(p\left(p^{*}\right)\right)=p^{M} \bar{F}\left(p^{M}\right)$.

Proposition 2 pins down the consumer-optimal advertising plan: the monopolist's price strictly decreases and the upward deviation to the original price must bind; moreover, it will be generically true that only this upward deviation will bind. ${ }^{29}$ This is in contrast to recent results on consumer-optimal information design which find that consumer-optimal information structures typically keep the monopolist indifferent between all upward deviations. ${ }^{30}$ This difference arises precisely because in our environment, if $p^{*}$ is already implementable, additional shifts of inframarginal consumers to further tighten the monopolist's upward deviation incentives cannot improve ex-ante consumer welfare.

Proposition 2 further delivers a computationally simple procedure for finding the

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{29}$ Generic the space of initial demand functions.
    ${ }^{30}$ See, e.g., Bergemann, Brooks, and Morris (2015); Roesler and Szentes (2017); Kartik and Zhong (2023).

consumer-optimal advertising plan: for each candidate target price $p^{*}<p^{M}$, simply check the monopolist's upward deviation constraint to $p^{M}$ : if it is fulfilled, then all other upward deviations are too since (i) $p^{M}$ is the lowest optimal price against the original distribution; and (ii) from Theorem 1 the optimal advertising map must leave the distribution after the target price $p^{*}$ unchanged.

Finally, observe that under the consumer-optimal advertising plan detailed by Proposition 2, advertising improves ex-post consumer welfare in the aggregate, but differentially across consumers. In particular, the core tradeoff is that to induce a lower target price $p^{*}$ to benefit inframarginal consumers, intermediate consumers must be manipulated to purchase the good against their own interests. ${ }^{31}$ Our analysis highlights how consumer-optimal advertising plans are both powerful-they can deliver substantially more surplus in the aggregate-but also necessarily regressive.

# 4 Advertising as complements 

We now adopt the view that advertising is a complementary good and delivers additional welfare to consumers: under this view, a type $x$ transported to $y \geq p$ enjoys a surplus of $y-p \geq 0$ from purchasing (Becker and Murphy, 1993). This view is consistent with the revealed preference approach so estimates of the effect of advertising on consumer welfare would measure $C S^{P}$.
Definition 1 ( $\alpha$-greedy transportation maps). Say that $\Lambda^{\alpha}$ is the $\alpha$-greedy transportation map if for each $x \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}, c_{y}\left(x, \Lambda^{\alpha}(x)\right)=\alpha$. That is, type $x$ 's valuation is increased until the marginal cost of doing so is exactly $\alpha$, the weight on consumer surplus. This preserves quantiles since $c(x, y)$ is submodular: $x \geq x^{\prime}$ implies $\Lambda^{\alpha}(x) \geq \Lambda^{\alpha}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$.

$$
T(x)= \begin{cases}\Lambda^{\alpha}(x) \wedge \frac{p^{*} q^{*}}{\bar{F}(x)} & \text { if } x \geq \bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right) \vee\left[\Lambda^{\alpha}\right]^{-1}\left(p^{*}\right) \\ p^{*} & \text { if } x \in\left[\bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right),\left[\Lambda^{\alpha}\right]^{-1}\left(p^{*}\right)\right) \\ x & \text { if } x<\bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right)\end{cases}

where the monopolist's optimal price is $p^{*}$ and $q^{*}:=\bar{F}_{\operatorname{mar}_{y} \pi^{*}}\left(p^{*}\right)$. Note that the middle region is empty if $\left[\Lambda^{\alpha}\right]^{-1}\left(p^{*}\right)<\bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right) .{ }^{32}$

Figure 6: Optimal advertising plans under ex-post welfare
![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

Theorem 2 pins down the optimal advertising plan which implements the price $p^{*}$ and quantity $q^{*}$. Figure 6 (a) illustrates the initial (inverse) demand curve $\bar{F}$ and the optimal target demand curve depicted by the thick black line which implements the price $p^{*}$ and quantity $q^{*}$. The consumer-optimal advertising plan splits consumers into three groups:

1. Excluded consumers: those with valuations $x<\bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right)$ are excluded.
2. Intermediate consumers: those with valuations $x \in\left[F^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right),\left[\Lambda^{a}\right]^{-1}\left(p^{*}\right)\right)$ have their valuations transported to $p^{*}$. For such consumers, it is sub-optimal to transport them beyond $p^{*}$ but nonetheless serves to shore up demand. This (i) improves producer surplus; and (ii) slackens the monopolist's upward deviations from the price $p^{*}$ which, in turn, allows more surplus to be delivered to inframarginal consumers.
3. Inframarginal consumers: those with valuations $x \geq \bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right) \vee\left[\Lambda^{a}\right]^{-1}\left(p^{*}\right)$ are transported to the lower envelope of $\Lambda^{a}$ and $\frac{p^{*} q^{*}}{\bar{F}(x)}$ which reflects two distinct constraints:

- Technological: $\Lambda^{a}$ is the final valuation at which the marginal cost of improving valuations is equal to the marginal gain from ex-post consumer surplus (given by $\alpha$ ). This is depicted by the blue curve in Figure 6 (a).
- Monopolist's incentive: $\frac{p^{*} q^{*}}{\bar{F}(x)}$ is the unit-elastic demand curve from the target price $p^{*}$ and quantity $q^{*}$ so that the monopolist's incentive from deviating to price $x>p^{*}$ is exactly tight. This is depicted by the red curve in Figure 6 (a).
Inframarginal consumers (region 3) are shifted to the lower envelope of the unit-elastic demand curve and the demand curve translated by $\Lambda^{a}(x)$ precisely

because optimal transport plans in our environment consist of comonotone (quantile-to-quantile) matching. This allows us to convert what would otherwise be global constraints on the monopolist's upward deviations into a local constraint on the pointwise optimal transportation distance for each consumer type $x$. Figure 6 (b) illustrates the transport map $T(x)$.

Theorem 2 makes precise how different groups of consumers are deployed to delicately balance surplus maximization while fulfilling the monopolist's incentive constraints. Suppose, for instance, that the designer is concerned solely with maximizing consumer surplus $(\alpha=1)$. The intermediate consumers (region 2 ) transported to valuation $p^{*}$ are employed to shore up quantities, which makes upward deviations from the target price $p^{*}$ less attractive. This is illustrated in Figure 7 where the bold red line is the unit-elastic demand curve induced by the target price $p^{*}$ and quantity $q^{\prime}>q^{*}$.

Figure 7: Tradeoffs associated with optimal advertising plans
![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)

The cost of choosing a higher target quantity $q^{\prime}>q^{*}$ is that consumers with valuations between $\bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{\prime}\right)$ and $\bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right)$-who were previously excluded-must now be shifted by more than what is pointwise optimal. Moreover, such consumers are not made better off since they previously did not purchase the product and now purchase at a price exactly equal to their new transformed valuation.

The benefit is that more inframarginal consumers (region 3) can be shifted to the expanded lower envelope (and made better-off from purchasing) while preserving the monopolist's incentives to set price $p^{*}$. Theorem 2 precisely highlights how the designer balances these competing forces. Moreover, it also sheds light on how consumer-optimal advertising plans necessarily improves ex-post consumer welfare differentially across consumers.

# 5 Comparing and quantifying prices and welfare. 

Theorems 1 and 2 pin down the general form of optimal advertising plans. We now use this to quantify the power of flexible demand manipulation.

Benchmarks. A helpful benchmark to isolate the impact of flexibility is to compare the designer's choice of $\Pi$ (all advertising plans) to a more restrictive classthe set of uniform advertising plans-we now define:

$$
\pi^{d}:=\{\pi \in \Pi: \int d \pi(x, x+d)=1\} \quad \text { and } \quad \Pi^{U}:=\bigcup_{d \geq 0} \pi^{d}

We will also compare the designer's choice of $\Pi$ (full flexibility) against the case with no advertising (with corresponding advertising plan $\pi^{0}$ ). To this end, define $p^{M}$ as the lowest optimal price which solves $\sup _{p} p \bar{F}(p)$. Finally, for this section we will assume, for simplicity, that the cost function is a strictly convex function of the transportation distance: $c(x, y)=\phi(y-x)$, where $\phi: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$strictly increasing, convex, $\phi(0)=\phi^{\prime}(0)=0$.

# 6 Discussion and implications for regulation 

Discussion. We have offered a simple but novel framework to study the impact of targeted advertising on prices and welfare. Our main results (Theorems 1 and 2) fully characterize the form of optimal advertising maps to maximize any combination of producer and consumer surplus. These results yield qualitative insights into the workings of flexible targeted advertising, as well as efficient numerical procedures for computing optimal advertising maps. We leveraged this to shed light on the power of targeted advertising to influence both efficiency as well as the surplus split.

Our model is deliberately stylized along several dimensions. We focused on a designer with the ability to both precisely (i) target (advertise different amounts to different types); and (ii) persuade (move valuations by a precise amount). This serves as a benchmark case to understand the impact of flexibility in product markets. Advertising is, of course, noisy in practice: not every consumer type is precisely known, and not every consumer's valuation can be precisely shifted. Within our framework, this would in effect restrict the set of available advertising maps since not every target distribution will be achievable. Our analysis can thus be viewed as the limit case as advertising technology becomes increasingly precise. We also focused on a monopoly pricing environment which serves as a helpful benchmark case; we expect the economic forces we have identified to carry through in a wider range of environments: as long as each firm has some residual market

power, there is room to flexibly manipulate demand. ${ }^{35}$
Implications for regulation. We briefly outline two stark policy implications. First, flexible demand manipulation can influence prices and welfare enormously. Targeted advertising is in practice a large, opaque, and heavily intermediated market where parties have differing incentives: the "supply side" selling consumer impressions might wish to safeguard consumer surplus such as to maintain a steady stream of web traffic while the "demand side" buying these impressions on behalf of firms might wish to maximize producer surplus. We have deliberated abstracted from the details of these markets. This has allowed us to obtain clean insights into the form of optimal advertising plans, and welfare possibilities of targeted advertising. Our results highlight how control of targeted advertising matters enormously for the distribution of consumer and producer surplus, and suggest the need for more transparency and regulatory scrutiny into these markets.

Second, banning targeted advertising-hence restricting the monopolist to uniform valuation shifts-typically ameliorates the decrease in consumer surplus, but does not improve it. ${ }^{36}$ Conversely, we also established the power of consumeroptimal advertising plans to (i) improve consumer surplus enormously; and (ii) improve total efficiency by lowering prices and facilitating trade. This suggests that more complex regulatory instruments might be able to harness the potential for flexible demand manipulation to improve total surplus. In Appendix C we develop a model of regulation as restricting the monopolist's menu of available transportation plans ${ }^{37}$ and fully characterize optimal regulation to maximize consumer surplus even when the monopolist is choosing from this restricted menu.

To see this, fix a sequence $p_{n} \rightarrow p$, proceeding to subsequences if necessary, we may assume the lower bound $p_{0}\left(p_{n}\right)=\inf \left\{x \geq 0:(1-\alpha) p_{n}+\alpha\left(x-p_{n}\right) \geq c\left(x, p_{n}\right)\right\}$ converges to some $\bar{p} \geq 0$. By definition $c\left(p_{0}\left(p_{n}\right), p_{n}\right) \geq 0$ for every $n$, so $c(\bar{p}, p) \geq 0$ by continuity of $c$. If $\bar{p}=0$, by definition we have $p_{0}(p)=0$. If $\bar{p}>0$, then we have $c(\bar{p}, p)=0$ as otherwise there exists $N$ such that $c\left(p_{0}\left(p_{n}\right), p_{n}\right)>0$ and $p_{0}\left(p_{n}\right)>0$ for all $n \geq N$, which contradicts with the definition of $p_{0}\left(p_{n}\right)$. It follows that $\bar{p}=p_{0}(p)$ since $c(\cdot, p)$ is strictly increasing. By the maximum theorem and the fact that $F$ is atomless, $\max _{x \geq p} x \bar{F}(x)$ is continuous.
Since $\underline{p}(p)$ is continuous, $h^{A}\left(p_{n}, x, T_{p_{n}}(x)\right)$ converges to $h^{A}\left(p, x, T_{p}(x)\right)$ pointwisely for every sequence $p_{n} \rightarrow p$. It is without loss to consider a bounded sequence, and let $P \geq \sup p_{n}$. Note that for every $n,\left|h^{A}\left(p_{n}, x, T_{p_{n}}(x)\right)\right| \leq(1-\alpha) P+\alpha x+c(0, P)$, which is integrable. Hence, by dominated convergence theorem, $\lim _{n} W\left(p_{n}\right)=$

$\int \lim _{n} h^{A}\left(p_{n}, x, T_{p_{n}}(x)\right)=\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} h^{A}\left(p, x, T_{p}(x)\right) \mathrm{d} F(x)=W(p)$. This establishes the continuity of $W$.
Finally, we show that $\sup _{\mu \geq r^{M}} W(p)$ admits a solution and thereby so is ( $\mathrm{D}^{\prime}$ ). Let $m$ be the median of $\mu$ and $\lambda=\log 2 / m>0$. Since $\mu$ has increasing hazard rate, Theorem 4.3 of Barlow and Proschan (1996) implies that $\bar{F}(x) \leq e^{-\lambda x}$ for $x \geq m$. By assumption, for every $p>k K, c\left(\frac{k-1}{k} p, p\right)>p$, which implies that $p_{0}(p)>\frac{k-1}{k} p$. Therefore, for every $p>\max \left\{k K, \frac{k}{k-1} m\right\}$, we have $p_{0}(p) \geq m$, and hence

$$
\int_{p_{0}}^{\infty} x \mathrm{~d} F(x)=p_{0} \bar{F}\left(p_{0}\right)+\int_{p_{0}}^{\infty} \bar{F}(x) \mathrm{d} x \leq\left(p_{0}+\frac{1}{\lambda}\right) e^{-\lambda p_{0}}
$$

where the equality follows from integrating by parts. Therefore, for every $p>$ $\max \left\{k K, \frac{k}{k-1} m\right\}$,

$$
W(p) \leq(1-\alpha) p \bar{F}\left(p_{0}\right)+\alpha \int_{p_{0}}^{\infty}(x-p) \mathrm{d} F(x) \leq\left((1-\alpha) p+\frac{\alpha}{\lambda}\right) e^{-\lambda \frac{k-1}{k} p} \rightarrow 0
$$

as $p \rightarrow+\infty$. Here, the first inequality holds as the right hand side is the value (without cost) of the pointwise optimal solution in ( $\mathrm{D}^{\prime}$ ) ignoring the incentive constraints given a fixed $p$. In particular, there exists $\bar{p}>r^{M}$ such that $W(p)<$ $(1-\alpha) r^{M}+\alpha \int_{p^{M}}^{\infty}\left(x-p^{M}\right) \mathrm{d} F(x)$ for all $p>\bar{p}$. Therefore, it is without loss to restrict $p$ to $\left[r^{M}, \bar{p}\right]$ in problem $\sup _{p \geq r^{M}} W(p)$, and a solution exists by the continuity of W.

# A. 3 Proof of Theorem 2. 

Lemma 4. For every $\alpha \in[0,1]$, the function

$$
r(x, p)=\max _{y \geq p} h^{p}(p, x, y)
$$

is continuous, strictly increasing in $x$ on $[0, p]$, and $r(p, p)>0$ for every $p \geq 0$.
Proof. By assumption, $\Lambda^{\alpha}(x)$ is the unique maximizer of $g(x, y)=\alpha y-c(x, y)$, which is a strictly concave function in $y$ for every $x$. Therefore,

$$
r(x, p)= \begin{cases}(1-\alpha) p-c(x, p) & \text { if } x \leq\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}(p) \\ (1-\alpha) p+\alpha\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}(x)-p\right)-c\left(x, \Lambda^{\alpha}(x)\right) & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

Note that $c(x, y)$ is strictly increasing in $x$, so $r(x, p)$ is strictly increasing in $x$ when $x \leq\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}(p)$. Moreover, for every $x^{\prime} \geq x, g\left(x^{\prime}, \Lambda^{\alpha}\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right) \geq g\left(x^{\prime}, \Lambda^{\alpha}(x)\right)>g\left(x, \Lambda^{\alpha}(x)\right)$, where the first inequality holds by definition of $\Lambda^{\alpha}$ and the second follows from strict monotonicity of $c$. This implies that $r(x, p)$ is strictly increasing in $x$ when $x>\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}(p)$. The continuity of $r$ follows from the continuity of $c$ and $\Lambda^{\alpha}$. Finally, $r(p, p)=(1-\alpha) p-\alpha p+g\left(p, \Lambda^{\alpha}(p)\right)>(1-\alpha) p-\alpha p+g(p, p)=(1-\alpha) p \geq 0$.

Recall that $\tau^{\alpha}(p)=\inf \{x \geq 0: r(x, p) \geq 0\}$. The preceding lemma implies that $\tau^{\alpha}(p)<p$.

Lemma 5. Suppose $h=h^{p}$ (ex-post measure). For any $\alpha \in[0,1]$, ( $\mathrm{D}^{\prime}$ ) admits a solution. For every optimal $\left(p^{*}, \pi^{*}\right)$, if $q^{*}=\bar{F}_{\operatorname{mar}_{q}} \pi^{*}\left(p^{*}\right)>\bar{F}\left(\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}\left(p^{*}\right)\right)$, then $\pi^{*}$ must be induced by the following map

$$
T(x)= \begin{cases}\Lambda^{\alpha}(x) \wedge \frac{p^{*} q^{*}}{\bar{F}(x)} & \text { if } x \geq\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}\left(p^{*}\right) \\ p^{*} & \text { if } x \in\left[\bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right),\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}\left(p^{*}\right)\right) \\ x & \text { if } x<\bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right)\end{cases}
$$

If $q^{*} \leq \bar{F}\left(\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}\left(p^{*}\right)\right)$, then $\pi^{*}$ must be induced by the following map

$$
T(x)= \begin{cases}\Lambda^{\alpha}(x) \wedge \frac{p^{*} q^{*}}{\bar{F}(x)} & \text { if } x \geq \bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right) \\ x & \text { if } x<\bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right)\end{cases}
$$

Proof. We first consider the inner problem and fix a $p \geq 0$. As in the proof of Lemma 2, since $c$ is strictly submodular, it suffices to consider joint distributions $\pi \in \Pi_{p}$ that are induced by some function in $I$. It suffices to consider the following problem

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\sup _{T \in I} & \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} h^{p}(p, x, T(x)) \mathrm{d} F(x) \\
\text { s.t. } & p \bar{F}_{T}(p) \geq p^{\prime} \bar{F}_{T}\left(p^{\prime}\right) \quad \text { for all } p^{\prime} \geq p
\end{array}
$$

Observation 1. Any feasible $T$ with $\bar{F}_{T}(p)<\bar{F}\left(\tau^{\alpha}(p)\right)$ is suboptimal.
Proof. For any feasible $T$, if $\bar{F}_{T}(p)<\bar{F}\left(\tau^{\alpha}(p)\right)$, then there exists $S \subseteq\left(\tau^{\alpha}(p), p\right)$ such that $\mu(S)>0$ and $T(x)<p$ for $x \in S$. Consider an alternative map $T^{\prime}$ such that $T^{\prime}(x)=p$ for every $x \in S$ and $T^{\prime}=T$ outside of $S$. By construction, $T^{\prime}$ is feasible as it is monotone and the incentive constraint is relaxed. It follows that $T^{\prime}$ leads to a strictly higher expected value than $T$ since $h^{p}(p, x, p)>0 \geq h^{p}(p, x, T(x))$ for every $x \in S$.

By the preceding observation, it suffices to consider the following problem

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sup _{q \in\left[\bar{F}\left(\tau^{\alpha}(p)\right), 1\right], T \in I} & \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} h^{p}(p, x, T(x)) \mathrm{d} F(x) \\
\text { s.t. } & q=\bar{F}_{T}(p) \\
& p q \geq p^{\prime} \bar{F}_{T}\left(p^{\prime}\right) \quad \text { for all } p^{\prime} \geq p
\end{aligned}
$$

where $q$ is a fictitious variable that keeps track of the induced demand after advertising. Fixing a $q \in\left[\bar{F}\left(\tau^{\alpha}(p)\right), 1\right]$ such that there are some feasible $T$.

Observation 2. For any feasible $T$, (a) $T(x) \geq p$ for every $x>\bar{F}^{-1}(q)$; (b) $T(x) \leq \frac{p q}{\bar{F}(x)}$ for every $x \geq \bar{F}^{-1}(q)$.

Proof. Suppose (a) is not true, then there exists $x_{0}>\bar{F}^{-1}(q)$ with $T\left(x_{0}\right)<p$ and hence $T\left(x^{\prime}\right)<p$ for every $x^{\prime}<x_{0}$ by monotonicity of $T$. It follows that $\bar{F}_{T}(p) \leq$ $\bar{F}\left(x_{0}\right)<q$, contradicting with the feasibility of $T$.
Suppose (b) does not hold, then there exists $x \geq \bar{F}^{-1}(q)$ such that $T(x)>\frac{p q}{\bar{F}(x)}$, then by monotonicity of $T$, we have $\bar{F}_{T}\left(\frac{p q}{\bar{F}(x)}\right)>\bar{F}(x)$, which implies that $\frac{p q}{\bar{F}(x)} \bar{F}_{T}\left(\frac{p q}{\bar{F}(x)}\right)>$ $\frac{p q}{\bar{F}(x)} \bar{F}(x)=p q$, contradicts with the feasibility of $T$.

Case 1. If $q>\bar{F}\left(\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}(p)\right)$, then this problem has a ( $\mu$-almost surely unique) solution $T_{p, q} \in I$ such that

$$
T_{p, q}(x)= \begin{cases}\Lambda^{\alpha}(x) \wedge \frac{p q}{\bar{F}(x)} & \text { if } x \geq\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}(p) \\ p & \text { if } x \in\left[\bar{F}^{-1}(q),\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}(p)\right) \\ x & \text { if } x<\bar{F}^{-1}(q)\end{cases}
$$

For every $x \leq \bar{F}^{-1}(q) \leq \tau^{\alpha}(p)$, by definition we know $\arg \max _{y \geq x} h^{P}(p, x, y)=x$. For every $x>\bar{F}^{-1}(q)$, by Observation 2(a), any feasible $T$ have $T(x) \geq p$. Moreover,

$$
\arg \max _{y \geq p} h^{P}(p, x, y)= \begin{cases}p & \text { if } x \in\left(\bar{F}^{-1}(q),\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}(p)\right) \\ \Lambda^{\alpha}(x) & \text { if } x \geq\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}(p)\end{cases}
$$

For $x \geq\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}(p), h^{P}(p, x, y)$ is strictly increasing in $y$ on $\left[p, \Lambda^{\alpha}(x)\right)$, so our construction of $T_{p, q}$ leads to the pointwise optimal shift for every $x \geq 0$ by Observation 2(b). One may check directly that the construction satisfies the incentive compatibility constraint.
Case 2. If $q \leq \bar{F}\left(\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}(p)\right)$, then this problem has a ( $\mu$-almost surely unique) solution $T_{p, q} \in I$ such that

$$
T_{p, q}(x)= \begin{cases}\Lambda^{\alpha}(x) \wedge \frac{p q}{\bar{F}(x)} & \text { if } x \geq \bar{F}^{-1}(q) \\ x & \text { if } x<\bar{F}^{-1}(q)\end{cases}
$$

For every $x \leq \bar{F}^{-1}(q) \leq \tau^{\alpha}(p)$, by definition we know $\arg \max _{y \geq x} h^{P}(p, x, y)=x$. For every $x>\bar{F}^{-1}(q)$, by Observation 2(a), any feasible $T$ have $T(x) \geq p$. Moreover, $\arg \max _{y \geq p} h^{P}(p, x, y)=\Lambda^{\alpha}(x)$ for every $x>\bar{F}^{-1}(q) \geq\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}(p)$, and $h^{P}(p, x, y)$ is strictly increasing in $y$ on $\left[p, \Lambda^{\alpha}(x)\right)$. Our construction of $T_{p, q}$ leads to the pointwise optimal shift for every $x \geq 0$, and one may check directly that the construction satisfies the incentive compatibility constraint.

Let $W(p, q):=\int_{\mathbb{R}}, h^{P}\left(p, x, T_{p, q}(x)\right) \mathrm{d} F(x)$. We show that $W$ is continuous. Since $\bar{F}$ and $\Lambda^{\alpha}$ are continuous, $h^{P}\left(p_{n}, x, T_{p_{n}, q_{n}}(x)\right)$ converges to $h^{P}\left(p, x, T_{p, q}(x)\right)$ pointwisely for every sequence $\left(p_{n}, q_{n}\right) \rightarrow(p, q)$. It is without loss to consider a bounded sequence, and let $P \geq \sup p_{n}$. Note that for every $n,\left|h^{P}\left(p_{n}, x, T_{p_{n}, q_{n}}(x)\right)\right| \leq(1-\alpha) P+\alpha|x+K-$ $p \mid+c(x, x+K) \vee c(0, P)$, which is integrable. By dominated convergence theorem, $\lim _{n} W\left(p_{n}, q_{n}\right)=W(p, q)$, which establishes the continuity of $W$.
Finally, we show that $\sup _{p \geq r^{M}, q \in\left\{\bar{F}\left(\tau^{\alpha}(p)\right), 1\right\}} W(p, q)$ admits a solution. Note that

$$
W(p, q) \leq(1-\alpha) p \bar{F}\left(\tau^{\alpha}(p)\right)+\alpha \int_{\tau^{\alpha}(p)}^{\infty}\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}(x)-p\right) \mathrm{d} F(x)
$$

where the right hand side is the value (without cost) of the pointwise optimal solution in ( $\mathrm{D}^{\prime}$ ) ignoring the incentive constraints given a fixed $p$. Let $p_{0}(p)=$ $\inf \{x \geq 0:(1-\alpha) p \geq c(x, p)\}$. By definition, we have $\tau^{\alpha}(p) \geq p_{0}(p) \wedge\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}(p)$.
By Assumption 1, we have $\Lambda^{\alpha}(x)<x+K$ for every $x \geq 0 .{ }^{40}$ By monotonicity of $\Lambda^{\alpha}$, we have $\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}(p)>p-K$. Therefore, for $p>k K,\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}\right)^{-1}(p)>\frac{k-1}{k} p$. Assumption 1 also implies that for every $p>k K, c\left(\frac{k-1}{k} p, p\right)>p$ and hence $p_{0}(p)>\frac{k-1}{k} p$. It follows that $\tau^{\alpha}(p)>\frac{k-1}{k} p$ for $p>k K$.
As $\mu$ has increasing hazard rate, Theorem 4.3 of Barlow and Proschan (1996) implies that $\bar{F}(x) \leq e^{-\lambda x}$ for $x \geq m$, where $m$ is the median of $\mu$. Therefore, for every $p>\max \left\{k K, \frac{k}{k-1} m\right\}$, we have $\tau^{\alpha}(p)>m$, and hence

$$
\int_{\tau^{\alpha}(p)}^{\infty}\left(\Lambda^{\alpha}(x)-p\right) \mathrm{d} F(x)<\int_{\tau^{\alpha}(p)}^{\infty}(x+K-p) \mathrm{d} F(x) \leq\left(\tau^{\alpha}(p)+K-p+\frac{1}{\lambda}\right) e^{-\lambda \tau^{\alpha}(p)}
$$

where the last equality follows from integrating by parts.
Therefore, for every $p>\max \left\{k K, \frac{k}{k-1} m\right\}$ and $q \in\left[\bar{F}\left(\tau^{\alpha}(p)\right), 1\right]$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
W(p, q) & \leq(1-\alpha) p \bar{F}\left(\tau^{\alpha}(p)\right)+\alpha\left(\tau^{\alpha}(p)+K-p+\frac{1}{\lambda}\right) e^{-\lambda \tau^{\alpha}(p)} \\
& \leq(1-\alpha) p e^{-\lambda \frac{k-1}{k} p}+\alpha\left(K+\frac{1}{\lambda}\right) e^{-\lambda \frac{k-1}{k} p} \rightarrow 0
\end{aligned}
$$

as $p \rightarrow+\infty$. There exists $\bar{p}>r^{M}$ such that $W(p, q)<(1-\alpha) P S\left(\pi^{0}\right)+\alpha C S\left(\pi^{0}\right)$ for all $p>\bar{p}$. Therefore, it is without loss to consider $\sup _{p \in\left\{r^{M}, \bar{p}\right\}, q \in\left\{\bar{F}\left(\tau^{\alpha}(p)\right), 1\right\}} W(p, q)$, and a solution exists by the continuity of $W$.

A. 5 Generalization of Theorem 1. Consider a general differentiable objective function

$$
h: \mathbb{R}^{3} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}
$$

with partial derivatives $h_{1}, h_{2} \geq 0>h_{3}$ and $\left|h_{1}\right| \leq\left|h_{3}\right|$. We also normalize $h(0,0,0)=$ 0 . Let $\mathcal{H}$ be the set of all such functions. The designer's problem is

$$
\sup _{\pi \in \Pi} h\left(P S(\pi), C S^{A}(\pi), \int c \mathrm{~d} \pi\right)
$$

With slight abuse of notation we denote $h(\pi)=h\left(P S(\pi), C S^{A}(\pi), \int c \mathrm{~d} \pi\right)$.
Theorem 1B. For any $h \in \mathcal{H}$, the designer's problem is uniquely solved by a deterministic advertising plan $\pi^{*} \in \Pi$ which takes an intermediate interval structure.

We prove Theorem 1B in several steps. The following lemma shows that any optimal solution has an intermediate interval structure.

Lemma 6. For every $\pi \in \Pi, \pi^{\prime} \in \Pi$ induced by

$$
T(x)= \begin{cases}x & \text { if } x \geq p^{*} \text { or } x<\bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right) \\ p^{*} & \text { if } x \in\left[\bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right), p^{*}\right)\end{cases}
$$

weakly dominates $\pi$, i.e. $h\left(\pi^{\prime}\right) \geq h(\pi)$, where $p^{*}=\min (\arg \max )_{p \geq 0} p \bar{F}_{\operatorname{mar}_{\mathrm{p}} \pi}(p)$ and $q^{*}=\bar{F}_{\operatorname{mar}_{\mathrm{p}} \pi}\left(p^{*}\right) .{ }^{42}$

Proof of Lemma 6. Fix a $\pi \in \Pi$, let $\pi^{\prime}$ as constructed in the lemma statement. We first show that $p^{*}$ is still the minimal best response for the monopolist given $\pi^{\prime}$, that is, $p^{*}=\min (\arg \max )_{p \geq 0} p \bar{F}_{\operatorname{mar}_{\mathrm{p}} \pi^{\prime}}(p)$. By construction, $\bar{F}_{\operatorname{mar}_{\mathrm{p}} \pi^{\prime}}(p)=q^{*}$ for $p \in\left[\bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right), p^{*}\right]$ and coincides with $\bar{F}(p)$ otherwise. Hence, in the former case, $p \bar{F}_{\operatorname{mar}_{\mathrm{p}} \pi^{\prime}}(p)=p q^{*} \leq p^{*} q^{*}$ with equality holds only at $p^{*}$; in the latter case, $p \bar{F}_{\operatorname{mar}_{\mathrm{p}} \pi^{\prime}}(p)=$ $p \bar{F}(p) \leq p \bar{F}_{\operatorname{mar}_{\mathrm{p}} \pi}(p) \leq p^{*} q^{*}$, where the first inequality holds because $\operatorname{mar}_{\mathrm{p}} \pi \geq_{s t} \mu$. It remains to show there's no $p<\bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right) \leq p^{*}$ that is a best response for the monopolist. Suppose there is such a $p$, then $p \bar{F}(p)=p^{*} q^{*}$ by our previous argument, it follows that $p \bar{F}_{\operatorname{mar}_{\mathrm{p}} \pi}(p)=p^{*} q^{*}$, violates the minimality of $p^{*}$ under $\pi$.
Since $p^{*}$ is still the minimal best response to $\pi^{\prime}, P S\left(\pi^{\prime}\right)=p^{*} q^{*}=P S(\pi)$ and $C S\left(\pi^{\prime}\right)=$ $\int_{\bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right)}^{\infty}\left(x-p^{*}\right) \mathrm{d} F(x)$. Next, we show $C S\left(\pi^{\prime}\right) \geq C S(\pi)=\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{n}} \mathbb{I}\left[y \geq p^{*}\right]\left(x-p^{*}\right) \mathrm{d} \pi(x, y)$. Since $\mathbb{I}\left[y \geq p^{*}\right]\left(x-p^{*}\right)$ is supermodular in $(x, y)$, there exists $\tilde{\pi} \in \Pi$ with the same marginal as $\pi$ that is induced by some $\tilde{T} \in I$ such that $C S(\tilde{\pi}) \geq C S(\pi)$. Note that $\tilde{T}\left(\bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right)\right) \geq p^{*}$ as otherwise $\bar{F}_{\operatorname{mar}_{\mathrm{p}}}\left(p^{*}\right)<q^{*}$. Therefore,

$$
C S\left(\pi^{\prime}\right)=\int_{\bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right)}^{\infty}\left(x-p^{*}\right) \mathrm{d} F(x) \geq \int_{\tilde{T}(x) \geq p^{*}}\left(x-p^{*}\right) \mathrm{d} F(x)=C S(\tilde{\pi}) \geq C S(\pi)
$$

where the first inequality holds because $\tilde{T}$ is increasing and $\bar{F}^{-1}\left(q^{*}\right) \leq p^{*}$.
As $c$ is strictly submodular, a similar argument as above shows that $\int c \mathrm{~d} \pi^{\prime} \leq \int c \mathrm{~d} \pi$. Therefore, $\pi^{\prime}$ leads to weakly higher PS and CS while reducing the cost. By our assumption on $h, h\left(\pi^{\prime}\right) \geq h(\pi)$.

By the preceding lemma, it is without loss to consider $\pi_{p, q} \in \Pi$ for some $p \geq 0$ and $q \geq \bar{F}(p)$, where $\pi_{p, q}$ is induced by $T_{p, q} \in I$ with $T_{p, q}(x)=p$ for all $x \in\left[\bar{F}^{-1}(q), p\right)$ and $T_{p, q}(x)=x$ otherwise, and $p q \geq p^{\prime} \bar{F}\left(p^{\prime}\right)$ for every $p^{\prime}>p$ and $p^{\prime}<\bar{F}^{-1}(q)$ (so that $p$ is the monopolist's best response given $\pi_{p, q}$ ). Let $S$ be the set of feasible pairs of $(p, q)$ that satisfies all these conditions, the designer's problem can be rewritten as $\sup _{(p, q) \in S} h\left(\pi_{p, q}\right)$. $$

where $h_{i}$ is the partial derivative with respect to the $i$-th coordinate evaluated at $\pi_{p, \bar{F}(\underline{p})}$. Since $p>k K$, by Assumption 1, we have $c\left(\frac{k-1}{k} p, p\right)>p$. Hence for any $\underline{p}<\frac{k-1}{k} p$, we have

$$

where the first inequality holds because $h_{2} \geq 0$ and $\underline{p} \leq p$, the second holds because $0<-h_{3}$ and $h_{1} \leq-h_{3}$, and the last one follows from the monotonicity of $c$ in the first entry. Since $\mu$ has increasing hazard rate, Theorem 4.3 of Barlow and Proschan (1996) implies that $\bar{F}(x) \leq e^{-\lambda x}$ for $x \geq m$, where $m$ is the median of $\mu$. Therefore, for every $p>\max \left\{k K, \frac{k}{k-1} m\right\}$, we have $\frac{k-1}{k} p>m$, and hence $p \bar{F}\left(\frac{k-1}{k} p\right) \leq p e^{-\lambda \frac{k-1}{k} p}$ and

$$
\int_{p}^{\infty}(x-p) \mathrm{d} F(x)=p \bar{F}(p)+\int_{p}^{\infty} \bar{F}(x) \mathrm{d} x \leq\left(p+\frac{1}{\lambda}\right) e^{-\lambda p}
$$

where the last equality follows from integrating by parts.

$$
\begin{aligned}

& \leq h\left(p e^{-\lambda \frac{k-1}{k} p},\left(p+\frac{1}{\lambda}\right) e^{-\lambda p}, 0\right) \rightarrow 0
\end{aligned}
$$

as $p \rightarrow+\infty$. There exists $\bar{p}>0$ such that $h\left(\pi_{p, q}\right)<h\left(\pi^{0}\right)$ for all $(p, q) \in S$ with $p>\bar{p}$.
Step 3. By step 2, it is without loss to consider $\sup _{(p, q) \in S, p \leq \bar{p}} h\left(\pi_{p, q}\right)$. One may check $S$ is closed and hence the restricted feasible set is compact, and a solution exists by the continuity of $h\left(\pi_{p, q}\right)$ in $(p, q)$ shown in step 1.

# Appendix B: Proofs of results in Section 5 

We first consider the producer-optimal comparison. By Proposition 1, the designer's problem when maximizing producer surplus can be rewritten as finding an optimal pair $\left(p^{\prime}, p\right)$, where $p$ is the price posted by the monopolist and the advertisement increases the valuations of all types $x \in\left[p^{\prime}, p\right)$ to $p$. That is, the designer's problem is $\max _{p \geq p^{\prime} \geq 0} \Pi\left(p^{\prime}, p\right)$, where $\Pi\left(p^{\prime}, p\right)=p \cdot \bar{F}\left(p^{\prime}\right)-\int_{p^{\prime}}^{p} \phi(p-x) \mathrm{d} F(x)$.
The first-order necessary conditions for $\left(p, p^{*}\right)$ to be optimal are

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} p} \Pi\left(p, p^{*}\right)=1-F(\underline{p})-\int_{\underline{p}}^{p^{*}} \phi^{\prime}\left(p^{*}-x\right) \mathrm{d} F(x)=0 \\
& \frac{\mathrm{~d}}{\mathrm{~d} p^{\prime}} \Pi\left(\underline{p}, p^{*}\right)=f(\underline{p})\left[\phi\left(p^{*}-\underline{p}\right)-p^{*}\right]=(\leq) 0
\end{aligned}
$$

If the advertising plan is restricted to $\Pi^{U}$, then the designer's problem can be rewritten as

$$
\sup _{0 \leq p^{\prime} \leq p} p \bar{F}\left(p^{\prime}\right)-\phi\left(p-p^{\prime}\right)
$$

The corresponding first-order conditions are

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{F}\left(\underline{p}^{U}\right)-\phi^{\prime}\left(p^{U}-\underline{p}^{U}\right) & =0 \\
-p^{U} f\left(\underline{p}^{U}\right)+\phi^{\prime}\left(p^{U}-\underline{p}^{U}\right) & =(\leq) 0
\end{aligned}
$$

# Appendix C: Optimal Regulation of Advertising Maps 

Definition 2. A regulation $R:=(\mathcal{G}, \bar{d})$ consists of:

- Limits on targeting. A partition $\mathcal{G}$ of $X$ i.e., for $g, g^{\prime} \in \mathcal{G}$ not equal, $g \cap g^{\prime}=\emptyset$ and $\bigcup_{g \in \mathcal{G}} g=X$.
- Limits on manipulation. A function $\bar{d}: X \rightarrow \overline{\mathbb{R}}_{+}$such that $\bar{d}(x)=\bar{d}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$ for every $x, x^{\prime} \in g$.
Let $\mathcal{R}$ be the set of all regulations. For every $x \geq 0$, let $\pi^{x} \in \Delta\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)$denote a version of the conditional distribution of $\pi$ given $x . R$ induces a set of feasible transport maps $\Pi[R]$ in the natural way:

The following are several canonical examples:

- Laissez-faire. There are no restrictions on targeting or manipulation:

$$
R:=\underbrace{(\{x\}: x \in X)}_{\begin{array}{c}
\text { No restriction } \\
\text { on targeting }
\end{array}}, \underbrace{\bar{d} \equiv+\infty}_{\begin{array}{c}
\text { No restriction } \\
\text { on manipulation }
\end{array}}
$$

and $\Pi[R]=\Pi$ i.e., all advertising plans are feasible.

- Bans on targeting. Each consumer's valuation must be transported by the same amount:

$$
R:=\underbrace{(\{X\})}_{\begin{array}{c}
\text { No } \\
\text { targeting }
\end{array}}, \underbrace{\bar{d} \equiv+\infty}_{\begin{array}{c}
\text { No restriction } \\
\text { on manipulation }
\end{array}}
$$

and $\Pi[R]=\Pi^{U}$.

- Limits on manipulation. Consumers can be flexibly targeted, but there is a limit on total manipulation:

$$
R=\underbrace{(\{x\}: x \in X)}_{\begin{array}{c}
\text { No restriction } \\
\text { on targeting }
\end{array}}, \underbrace{\bar{d} \equiv D}_{\begin{array}{c}
\text { Cap on } \\
\text { manipulation }
\end{array}}
$$

where $D>0$ is a constant.

$$
\Pi[R]=\{\pi \in \Pi: \int_{y \leq x+D} \mathrm{~d} \pi(x, y)=1\}
$$

The regulator's problem is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sup _{R \in \mathcal{R}, \pi^{*} \in \Pi[R]} C S^{A}\left(\pi^{*}\right) \\
& \text { s.t. } \pi^{*} \text { solves } \sup _{\pi \in \Pi[R]} P S(\pi)-\int c(x, y) d \pi
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 3 (Optimal regulation). There exists a deterministic and comonotone map $\pi^{*}$ with an intermediate interval structure characterized by $\left(\underline{p}, p^{*}\right)$ such that $R\left(\pi^{*}\right)$ solves (REG) where

$$
\begin{gathered}
R^{*}:=\left(\left\{\left\{X \backslash[\underline{p}, p^{*}]\right\},\left\{\{x\}: x \in[\underline{p}, p^{*}]\right\}\right.\right. \\
\tilde{d}(x)=\left(p^{*}-x\right) \mathbb{I}\left(x \in\left[\underline{p}, p^{*}\right)\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

and this strictly improves consumer welfare: $R E G>C S\left(\pi^{0}\right)$.
Proof. Define a relaxed problem:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sup _{\pi \in \Pi} C S^{A}(\pi) \\
& \text { s.t. }\left(P S(\pi)-P S\left(\pi^{0}\right)\right) \geq \int c(x, y) d \pi
\end{aligned}
$$

Observe $R E L \geq R E G$ since for any $(R, \pi \in \Pi[R])$ feasible in (REG), $P S(\pi)-\int c \mathrm{~d} \pi \geq$ $P S\left(\pi^{0}\right)-\int c \mathrm{~d} \pi^{0}=P S\left(\pi^{0}\right)$ and hence $\pi$ is feasible in (REL).

Lemma 7. The solution to (REL) is deterministic and monotone with an intermediate interval structure characterized by $\left(\underline{p}, p^{*}\right)$.

Proof. First, observe that it is without loss to restrict to comonotone deterministic maps. Because fixing the marginals and changing to assortative matching does not affect the objective value and the IC constraint (hidden in definition of PS), the IR constraint is slackened (the explicit constraint written).
Those maps are induced by increasing functions $T$ with $T(x) \geq x$. For any feasible $T$, consider $T^{\prime}$ such that $T^{\prime}(x)=x$ if $x \geq p$ or $x<p$ with $T(x)<p$, and $T^{\prime}(x)=p$ if $x<p$ with $T(x) \geq p$. The induced demand $\bar{F}_{T^{\prime}}(p)=\bar{F}_{T}(p)$ while $\bar{F}_{T^{\prime}}\left(p^{\prime}\right) \leq \bar{F}_{T}\left(p^{\prime}\right)$ for every $p^{\prime} \geq 0$ so the IC is slackened. The IR is also slacked since the total cost decreases. The CS weakly increases since the cost of manipulation goes down. Therefore, for any fixed price, it is without loss to consider $T$ such that $T(x)=x$ if $x \notin[\underline{p}, p)$ and $T(x)=p$ otherwise.

Similar arguments as in the proof of Theorem 1 show that it is without loss to restrict to a compact set of $p$, so there exists a solution of (REL). Note that this

construction proof also shows $P S\left(\pi^{*}\right)-\int c \mathrm{~d} \pi^{*}=P S\left(\pi^{0}\right)$ at the optimal solution $\pi^{*}$.

We will construct $R^{*}$ such that $R E L$ can be attained under (REG):

$$
\begin{gathered}
R^{*}:=\left(\left\{\left\{X \backslash\left[\underline{p}, p^{*}\right)\right\},\left\{\{x\}: x \in\left[\underline{p}, p^{*}\right)\right\}\right\}\right. \\
\tilde{d}(x)=\left(p^{*}-x\right) \mathbb{I}\left(x \in\left[\underline{p}, p^{*}\right)\right)\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

To see this, we need to ensure that a solution to the problem

$$
\sup _{\pi \in \Pi\left[R^{*}\right], p \geq 0} p \bar{F}_{\operatorname{mar}_{\underline{p}} \pi}(p)-\int c(x, y) d \pi
$$

is indeed $\left(\pi^{*}, p^{*}\right)$, the solution of (REL) and the corresponding optimal price. Assume to the contrary that it is not and that it is strictly dominated by $\left(\pi^{\prime}, p^{\prime}\right) \neq$ $\left(\pi^{*}, p^{*}\right)$.
If $p^{\prime}<p^{*}$, then the corresponding optimal map $\pi^{\prime} \in \Pi\left[R^{*}\right]$ transports some types in $\left[p^{\prime}, p^{\prime}\right)$ exactly to $p^{\prime}$ where $\underline{p}^{\prime} \geq \underline{p}$. But then ex-ante CS must strictly improve since (i) weakly fewer types are being manipulated; and (ii) $p^{\prime}<p^{*}$. This contradicts the optimality of $\pi^{*}$ in (REL).
If $p^{\prime} \geq p^{*}$, then no $\pi \in \Pi\left[R^{*}\right]$ can improve demand given $p^{\prime}$, so the corresponding optimal advertising plan must be $\pi^{\prime}=\pi^{0}$. Since $\left(\pi^{*}, p^{*}\right)$ is strictly dominated by $\left(\pi^{\prime}, p^{\prime}\right)$, we have

$$
p^{*} \bar{F}\left(p^{\prime}\right)>p^{*} \bar{F}\left(p^{*}\right)-\int c \mathrm{~d} \pi^{*}=\sup _{p} p \bar{F}(p)
$$

which is a contradiction. In either case there is a contradiction which implies $\left(\pi^{*}, p^{*}\right)$ is a solution.

# Appendix D: Intermediated targeting advertising 

We now embed the model of targeted advertising we developed in the main text into a larger model of the market for digital advertising. Our model comprises three types of players:

1. Consumers. There is a unit measure of consumers with hetrogeneous options on whether or not to use the platform distributed $\eta$ with CDF $H$. Their decision on whether to use the platform depends on their expected consumer surplus.
2. Intermediary. The intermediary has knowledge of consumer types, and has access to consumers. This might correspond to "supply side platforms" (henceforth, SSPs), or a large e-commerce platform like Amazon. The intermediary controls the set of available advertising plans on offer, and raises revenue by selling such plans to the monopolist. ${ }^{44}$
3. Firm. There is a monopolist choosing from the set of advertising plans. In practice, this is not done directly by the firm, but by "demand side platforms" (henceforth, DSPs) who act on the firm's behalf and decide which advertising plan to purchase to maximize producer surplus.

The timing of the game is as follows:

- $t=1$ : Each consumer decides whether or not to use the platform
- $t=2$ : Conditional on participation, each consumer's valuation $x \in X$ is drawn independently from the distribution $\mu .{ }^{45}$ These valuations are observed by the intermediary and the intermediary chooses an advertising plan and transfer pair $(\Pi, t)$ as a take-it-or-leave-it offer to the firm.
- $t=3$ : The firm, facing this advertising plan and transfer pair, decides whether to engage in advertising. If the firm engages in advertising, it pays the intermediary the transfer and the intermediary advertises on the firm's behalf. The firm then sets an optimal price against the transformed demand curve. If the firm does not engage in advertising, it sets an optimal price against the initial demand curve
- $t=4$ : Payoffs are realized for the intermediary, firm, and consumers.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{44}$ See Bergemann and Bonatti (2024) for an elegant model of how platforms might raise revenue by selling access to consumers; the crucial difference in our model is that the platform is selling targeted advertising plans which manipulates valuations.
    ${ }^{45}$ We have in mind the intermediary as a gateway to many products, and dispersion in valuations for each product is driven by horizontal differentiation so that aggregating across products, expected individual consumer welfare is independent from the outside option.

The measure of consumers $\rho$ who participate is an increasing function of expected consumer surplus: $\rho=H(C S)$ where $H(C S)$ is the measure of consumers with outside options below CS. Then, the intermediary's problem is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sup _{(\pi, t) \in\left(\Pi, \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}\right)} t-H(C S(\pi)) \int c(x, y) d \pi \\
& \text { s.t. } H(C S(\pi)) \cdot P S(\pi)-H\left(C S\left(\pi^{0}\right)\right) \cdot P S\left(\pi^{0}\right) \geq t
\end{aligned}
$$

where the constraint follows from firm participation. This problem can be rewritten as

$$
\sup _{\pi \in \Pi} H(C S(\pi)) \cdot\left(P S(\pi)-\int c(x, y) d \pi\right)
$$

and letting $\pi^{*}$ be the solution, set $t^{*}:=H\left(C S\left(\pi^{*}\right)\right) \cdot P S\left(\pi^{*}\right)-H\left(C S\left(\pi^{0}\right)\right) \cdot P S\left(\pi^{0}\right)$. Now note that the problem (INT) is handled by Theorem 1B which generalizes our characterization of ex-ante consumer-optimal advertising plans to the case in which consumer-surplus, producer-surplus, and advertising costs are non-separable.

# Appendix E: Heterogeneity in susceptibility to manipulation 

In the main text, we assumed for simplicity that consumer were heterogeneous only along their valuations. Implicit in this assumption is that consumers with the same valuations have identical manipulation costs. We now introduce heterogeneity along this dimension, which captures how susceptible to manipulation different consumers are.

Augmenting the main model. Let $S$ be a compact set. The augmented type space is $\widetilde{X}:=X \times S$ (which remains compact). Consumers are distributed according to $\widetilde{\mu} \in \Delta(\widetilde{X})$ and, consistent with notation in the main text, we let $\mu:=\operatorname{marg}_{X} \widetilde{\mu}$ denote the marginal over valuations. The cost of transporting type $(x, s)$ to $(y, s)$ is $c_{s}(x, y)$ where we impose Assumption 1 on $c_{s}$ for each $s \in S$. We further impose the assumption of monotonicity in susceptibility:

$$
s \geq s^{\prime} \Longrightarrow c_{s}(x, y) \leq c_{s^{\prime}}(x, y) \quad \text { for all } x, y \in X
$$

A transport plans $\pi \in \Delta(\widetilde{X} \times \widetilde{X})$ is admissible if it concentrates on the set

$$
\widetilde{\mathbb{H}}:=\left\{\left((x, s),(y, s)\right) \in \widetilde{X}^{2}: y \geq x\right\}
$$

Let $\widetilde{\Pi}$ be the set of all admissible transport plans. Admissible plans are those which (i) weakly improve willingness-to-pay as in the main text, and (ii) leave the susceptibility dimension $s$ unchanged.

The designer's problem in the ex-ante case with heterogeneous susceptibility to manipulation is

$$
\sup _{\widetilde{\pi} \in \widetilde{\Pi}} \alpha C S(\widetilde{\pi})+(1-\alpha) P S(\widetilde{\pi})-\int c_{s}(x, y) d \widetilde{\pi}
$$

Say that the transport plan $T$ takes on a monotone intermediate interval form for the decreasing threshold $\gamma(s)$ and target price $p$ such that

$$
T_{\gamma, p}(x, s):= \begin{cases}(x, s) & \text { if } x \leq \gamma(s) \\ (p, s) & \text { if } x \in[\gamma(s), p) \\ (y, s) & \text { if } y \geq p\end{cases}
$$

Theorem 1C. For any $\alpha \in[0,1],(\mathrm{H})$ is uniquely solved by an advertising map with a monotone intermediate interval form i.e., there exists $\gamma, p$ such that the advertising plan induced by $T_{\gamma, p}$ attains (H).

abstract:
We develop a simple framework to analyze how targeted advertising interacts
with market power. A designer chooses an advertising plan which allows it to
flexibly manipulate the demand curve at some cost. A monopolist prices against
this manipulated demand curve. We fully characterize the form and value of
producer-optimal and consumer-optimal advertising plans under both ex-ante and
ex-post measures of welfare. Flexibility is double-edged: producer-optimal
plans substantially reduce consumer surplus vis-a-vis uniform advertising, but
consumer-optimal plans can substantially improve consumer surplus. We discuss
implications for the regulation of targeted advertising.
